Exaggerate: The claim may be exaggerating the extent to which economic gains have been made by the richest 1 percent since Barack Obama became president.
Lack enough support: The claim may lack enough supporting evidence or data to fully substantiate the assertion that 95 percent of economic gains have been made by the richest 1 percent.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the economic gains made by the richest 1 percent are solely attributed to Barack Obama's presidency, without considering other factors or policies.
Exist alternative explanation: There may be alternative explanations or factors contributing to income inequality, such as the inclusion of government assistance programs or the measurement of consumption instead of income.
